docs.title: Overall Design Philosophy
docs.text: Create a clean, scalable documentation system inspired by the marvelousdesigner project structure but focused entirely on board game content. The architecture emphasizes maintainability, user experience, and future growth.

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• Documentation Framework: MKDocs with Material theme
  • Content Format: Markdown files with YAML frontmatter
  • Styling: Custom CSS for board game-specific elements
  • Search: Built-in MKDocs search with lunr.js
  • Deployment: Static site generation

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text: A smart board game rule book documentation system that enables users to easily find and read rulebooks for their board games. The platform focuses on providing comprehensive, structured documentation for board games with special emphasis on player accessibility and searchability.

docs.title: 1. Mandatory Board Games
docs.text: The system must include the following specific board games: - BOHNANZA (ボーナンザ) - Classic bean trading card game - HackClad (魔女魔石) - Witch-themed deck-building game - イスタンブール選択と集中 (Istanbul: Choose & Write) - Strategic merchant game variant - FORT (掏蛋王国) - Kids fort-building deck-builder - FIXER (フィクサー) - Political manipulation trick-taking game - National Economy Mesena (ナショナルエコノミー・メセナ) - Cultural economy worker placement game

docs.title: 2. Game Information Structure
docs.text:
Each board game entry must include: - Basic Information - Official English and Japanese names - Player count (minimum/maximum/recommended) - Play time (minutes) - Recommended age range - Complexity rating (1-5 scale) - BGG (BoardGameGeek) rating and link

  • Gameplay Content
  • Complete rule summary
  • Detailed instructions
  • Cards/goods/items lists
  • Setup instructions

  • Win conditions

  • Metadata & Tags

  • BGG Score integration
  • 所持 (Ownership) status
  • BGA (Board Game Arena) availability
  • Genre/category classification
  • Designer and publisher information

docs.title: 3. User Experience Requirements
docs.text:
• All-in-One Documentation: Each game's complete rulebook accessible on a single MKDocs page
  • Easy Navigation: Users can quickly find the rulebook they want to read
  • Sorting & Filtering: Filter by player count, time, genre, and other criteria
  • Search Functionality: Text-based search across all game content
  • Mobile Responsive: Accessible on all device types

docs.title: 4. Technical Architecture Requirements
docs.text:
• Scalable Design: Architecture must accommodate growing number of board games
  • Multi-User Support: Designed for humans, AI, LLM, Serena-MCP, developers, and players
  • Documentation Framework: Built with MKDocs for clean, beautiful documentation
  • Agent-Based Development: Utilize specialized agents for different aspects (architect, writer, organizer, searcher, manager)

docs.title: 5. Content Management
docs.text:
• Clean Architecture: Avoid junk files and maintain organized structure
  • Version Control: Proper git management with clear commit history
  • Quality Control: Standardized formatting and content structure
  • Multilingual Support: Handle both English and Japanese content appropriately

docs.title: 6. Integration Requirements
docs.text:
• BGG Integration: Pull ratings and information from BoardGameGeek
  • BGA Status: Track Board Game Arena availability
  • External Links: Link to official rules, BGG pages, and other resources

docs.title: BOHNANZA (ボーナンザ)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Players: 2-7 | Time: 45 minutes | Complexity: 1.6/5 BGG Rating: 7.0/10 | Available on BGA: Yes

docs.title: Game Overview
docs.text:
BOHNANZA is a brilliant card game about bean farming and trading. Players cultivate different types of beans in their fields, harvesting them for coins when they have enough of the same type. The key twist: you must play cards in the order you draw them, making trading essential for success.

The game combines hand management, negotiation, and timing in a unique way that creates constant player interaction and difficult decisions about when to harvest your beans.

docs.title: Bean Cards (154 cards)
docs.text:
• Coffee Bean (24 cards): Most common, lowest value
  • Wax Bean (22 cards): Second most common
  • Blue Bean (20 cards): Medium frequency
  • Chili Bean (18 cards): Less common, higher value
  • Stink Bean (16 cards): Rare, valuable
  • Green Bean (14 cards): Very rare
  • Soy Bean (12 cards): Extremely rare
  • Black-Eyed Bean (10 cards): Ultra rare
  • Red Bean (8 cards): Legendary rarity
  • Garden Bean (6 cards): Mythical rarity
  • Cocoa Bean (4 cards): Ultimate rarity

docs.title: Bean-O-Meter Cards (11 cards)
docs.text: One for each bean type showing harvest values and rarity.

docs.title: Coin Tokens
docs.text: Gold coins earned from harvesting beans.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Shuffle all bean cards into one deck
  2. Deal cards to each player:
  3. 2-3 players: 7 cards each
  4. 4-5 players: 6 cards each
  5. 6-7 players: 5 cards each
  6. Place Bean-O-Meter cards face up where all players can see them
  7. Set aside coin tokens within reach of all players
  8. Place remaining cards face down as the draw pile

Hand Order Rule

Players must keep their cards in the order received and never rearrange them. This is crucial to the game!

docs.title: Game Round Structure
docs.text: Each player's turn consists of three phases:

docs.title: Phase 1: Must Plant (Mandatory)
docs.text:
1. Plant the front card from your hand into one of your bean fields
  2. Optionally plant the second card if it matches a bean already in one of your fields

docs.title: Phase 2: Draw and Trade (Optional but Recommended)
docs.text:
1. Draw 2 cards from the deck and place them face up
  2. Trade Phase: All players can now trade cards
  3. You may trade the 2 face-up cards you just drew
  4. You may trade cards from your hand (but must give away cards from the front)
  5. Other players may trade cards from their hands
  6. All trades must be beneficial to both parties

docs.title: Phase 3: Plant Traded and Drawn Cards (Mandatory)
docs.text:
1. Plant all face-up cards (the 2 you drew plus any you received in trades)
  2. Harvest if necessary when you need space for new beans

docs.title: Phase 4: Draw Cards (Mandatory)
docs.text:
1. Draw 3 cards from the deck
  2. Add them to the back of your hand in the order drawn

docs.title: Bean Fields
docs.text:
• Every player starts with 2 bean fields
  • Each field can contain only one type of bean
  • A third field can be purchased with coins (costs vary by player count)
  • Fields must be harvested entirely - you cannot remove individual cards

docs.title: Harvesting
docs.text:
When you harvest a field:

  1. Count the beans in that field
  2. Consult the Bean-O-Meter for that bean type
  3. Take coins equal to the harvest value shown
  4. Place one harvested bean card face up in front of you as a coin (= 1 coin)
  5. Return remaining cards to the discard pile
  6. Field is now empty and ready for new beans

Harvesting Strategy

Rarer beans give more coins for fewer cards, but they're harder to collect. Common beans require more cards but are easier to accumulate.

docs.title: Trading Rules
docs.text:
• Voluntary participation: Only players who want to trade need to participate
  • Mutual benefit: All trades must benefit both parties
  • No promises: Players cannot promise future actions or trades
  • Hand order matters: If trading from hand, must give cards from the front
  • Active player priority: The current player decides what happens with their drawn cards

docs.title: Winning
docs.text:
The game ends when the deck is exhausted for the third time. Players then:

  1. Harvest all remaining fields
  2. Count total coins (both physical coins and face-up bean cards)
  3. Player with the most coins wins

docs.title: Turn Summary
docs.text:
1. Must Plant: Front card, optionally second if matching
  2. Draw & Trade: Draw 2 cards, trade freely with all players
  3. Plant Traded: Must plant all face-up cards received
  4. Draw: Add 3 cards to back of hand

docs.title: Bean Values (from Bean-O-Meter)
docs.text: Bean Type Cards 2-coin 3-coin 4-coin Garden 6 N/A 2 3 Red 8 N/A 2 3-4 Black-Eyed 10 2 4 5-6 Soy 12 2 4 6-7 Green 14 3 5 6-7 Stink 16 3 5 7-8 Chili 18 3 6 8-9 Blue 20 4 6 8-10 Wax 22 4 7 9-11 Coffee 24 4 7 10-12

docs.title: Key Reminders
docs.text:
• ✅ Never rearrange your hand
  • ✅ Must plant front cards when trading from hand
  • ✅ All face-up cards must be planted
  • ✅ Trading is voluntary but often essential
  • ✅ Third field costs coins (varies by player count)

docs.title: FIXER (フィクサー)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Players: 3-4 | Time: 30 minutes | Complexity: 2.0/5 BGG Rating: 6.8/10 | Available on BGA: No

docs.title: Game Overview
docs.text:
FIXER is a political trick-taking game where players are shadowy power brokers manipulating elections behind the scenes. You'll play cards to win tricks, but the real challenge is managing your political influence and timing your interventions for maximum impact.

Unlike traditional trick-taking games, FIXER combines classic card play with area control elements, where winning tricks in specific regions gives you political influence that translates into victory points.

docs.title: Playing Cards (60 cards total)
docs.text: The deck consists of 4 suits representing different political regions: - Urban (Blue) - 15 cards: Values 1-15, representing city districts - Suburban (Green) - 15 cards: Values 1-15, representing suburban areas - Rural (Red) - 15 cards: Values 1-15, representing rural constituencies - Industrial (Yellow) - 15 cards: Values 1-15, representing industrial zones

docs.title: Special Action Cards (12 cards)
docs.text:
• Media Manipulation: Change trump suit mid-trick
  • Scandal Cards: Force opponents to discard high cards
  • Endorsement: Boost your card values in specific suits
  • Investigation: Reveal opponent hands for information

docs.title: Influence Tokens (48 tokens)
docs.text:
• 4 colors matching the suits: Track regional political control
  • 12 tokens per region: Maximum influence per area

docs.title: Victory Point Cards
docs.text: Cards showing various scoring conditions and political achievements.

docs.title: Player Boards (4 boards)
docs.text: Track influence in each region and special abilities.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Deal cards based on player count:
  2. 3 players: 15 cards each, remove 15 cards from game
  3. 4 players: 12 cards each, remove 12 cards from game
  4. Place influence tokens organized by color near player boards
  5. Shuffle special action cards, deal 2 to each player face down
  6. Place victory point cards face up where all can see
  7. Determine starting player (youngest goes first)

Setup Variation

For more strategic play, deal action cards face up so all players can see who has which special abilities.

docs.title: Game Structure
docs.text: FIXER is played over multiple rounds of trick-taking, with political maneuvering between rounds.

docs.title: Trick-Taking Phase
docs.text:
1. Lead Player plays any card from their hand
  2. Following Players must follow suit if possible
  3. Trump Suit: The region with the most influence tokens is trump
  4. Highest Card Wins: Unless trumped by a higher card of trump suit
  5. Winner Takes Trick: Gains political influence in that region

docs.title: Influence Resolution
docs.text: When you win a trick: 1. Gain Influence: Place influence tokens equal to the number of cards in the trick 2. Choose Region: Distribute influence among the suits played in the trick 3. Trump Benefits: Extra influence for cards matching trump suit 4. Maximum Limit: Cannot exceed 12 influence in any single region

docs.title: Special Actions
docs.text: Players can use action cards at specific times: - During Trick: Media Manipulation, Endorsements - Before Trick: Scandal reveals, Investigation - After Trick: Influence adjustments

docs.title: Trump Suit Changes
docs.text: The trump suit shifts based on regional influence: - Most Influence: Region with highest total influence becomes trump - Tied Regions: Previous trump suit continues - Strategic Implications: Players can manipulate trump by gaining influence

docs.title: Regional Control
docs.text:
• Dominant Player: Player with most influence in a region controls it
  • Tied Control: All tied players share control benefits
  • Control Benefits: Bonus points and special abilities

docs.title: Immediate Victory
docs.text:
• Total Domination: Control all 4 regions simultaneously
  • Super Majority: Have 30+ total influence across all regions
  • Political Coup: Complete specific victory point card conditions

docs.title: End of Game Scoring (if no immediate victory)
docs.text:
Game ends when the deck is exhausted:

  1. Regional Control: 3 points per controlled region
  2. Influence Majority: 2 points per region where you have most influence
  3. Victory Point Cards: Bonus points for completed political objectives
  4. Action Cards: Some provide end-game scoring bonuses
  5. Tie-Breaker: Player with most total influence wins

docs.title: Trick-Taking Rules
docs.text:
• Follow Suit: Must play same suit if possible
  • Trump: Region with most influence tokens
  • Winning: Highest card of led suit, or highest trump
  • Influence Gain: Number of cards in trick distributed among played suits

docs.title: Influence Limits
docs.text:
• Maximum per Region: 12 influence tokens
  • Trump Benefits: +1 influence for trump suit cards
  • Control Threshold: Most influence in region = control

docs.title: Special Action Timing
docs.text: Action Type When to Play Effect Media Manipulation During trick Change trump suit Scandal Before trick Force card discard Endorsement With your card +2 to card value Investigation Any time Reveal opponent hand

docs.title: Victory Conditions
docs.text:
• ✅ Control all 4 regions: Immediate victory
  • ✅ 30+ total influence: Immediate victory
  • ✅ Complete victory card: Immediate victory
  • ✅ Most points at end: Standard victory

docs.title: Early Game
docs.text:
• Focus on gaining influence in multiple regions
  • Don't dominate one region too early (makes you a target)
  • Save powerful action cards for crucial moments

docs.title: Mid Game
docs.text:
• Start pushing for regional control
  • Watch trump suit changes and adapt strategy
  • Use scandal cards to disrupt opponent plans

docs.title: Late Game
docs.text:
• Push for immediate victory conditions
  • Block opponents from achieving victory
  • Time action cards for maximum disruption

docs.title: General Tips
docs.text:
• Information: Track which cards have been played
  • Timing: Save high cards for important tricks
  • Flexibility: Adapt to changing trump suits
  • Politics: Sometimes help opponents to prevent others from winning

docs.text:

  • Strategy Guide - Advanced tactics
  • Trick-Taking Games - Similar games

docs.title: FORT (フォート)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Players: 2-4 | Time: 40 minutes | Complexity: 2.1/5 BGG Rating: 7.4/10 | Available on BGA: Yes

docs.title: Game Overview
docs.text:
FORT is a charming deck-building game about childhood friendships and fort-building. Players recruit kids from the neighborhood to help build the ultimate fort, but friendships are fickle - unused friends might abandon you for other players!

The game features a unique "follow" mechanic where other players can benefit from your actions, and a friendship system where neglected cards can be stolen by opponents, creating constant tension between card efficiency and relationship maintenance.

docs.title: Friend Cards (120+ cards)
docs.text: Each representing a neighborhood kid with: - Name and artwork: Unique character design - Suit color: Public (white) or Private (colored) - Pizza/Toy values: Resources the friend provides - Special abilities: Unique effects when played

docs.title: Starting Decks (4 identical sets)
docs.text:
• 5 Maiko cards: Your best friend (2 Pizza, 1 Toy)
  • 2 Interesting Kid cards: Basic friends
  • 3 Shy Kid cards: Minimal resources but reliable

docs.title: Fort Boards (4 player boards)
docs.text: Track your fort's development and special abilities.

docs.title: Resource Tokens
docs.text:
• Pizza tokens: Primary currency
  • Toy tokens: Secondary currency

docs.title: Lookout Tokens
docs.text: Mark friends that can't be stolen this round.

docs.title: 1. Play a Friend (Mandatory)
docs.text:
• Choose one friend card from your hand
  • Gain Pizza and/or Toys shown on the card
  • Activate any special abilities
  • Place played card in your discard pile

docs.title: 2. Follow Opportunities (All Players)
docs.text:
• Other players may "follow" your action
  • To follow: discard a card matching the suit of the played friend
  • Following players gain reduced benefits
  • Only the active player gets full benefits and abilities

docs.title: 3. Make Best Friends (Optional)
docs.text:
• Spend resources to recruit new friends from the Park (market)
  • Best Friend cards go directly to your hand
  • Regular friends go to your discard pile
  • Some friends have recruitment requirements

docs.title: 4. Fort Building (Optional)
docs.text:
• Spend resources to advance your Fort track
  • Gain permanent abilities and victory points
  • Some Fort levels provide end-game scoring bonuses

docs.title: 5. Clean Up
docs.text:
• Friends you didn't use can be "stolen"
  • Other players can recruit unused friends from your yard
  • Draw back up to your hand size
  • Refresh the Park if needed

docs.title: Following System
docs.text:
• When someone plays a friend, you can follow by discarding a matching suit
  • Following gives you partial benefits without using your turn
  • Creates tough decisions about when to help others

docs.title: Friend Stealing
docs.text:
• Unused friends in your hand become vulnerable
  • Other players can recruit them during their turns
  • Use Lookout tokens to protect specific friends
  • Stolen friends go to the recruiting player's discard pile

docs.title: Suit Colors
docs.text:
• Public Friends (white): Anyone can follow these
  • Private Friends (colored): Only players with matching suits can follow
  • Best Friends: Always private, powerful abilities

docs.title: Fort Development
docs.text: Your fort grows stronger throughout the game: - Level 1-2: Basic fort abilities - Level 3-4: Intermediate powers and scoring - Level 5: Major abilities and victory points - Level 6: End-game bonus scoring

docs.title: Winning
docs.text: The game ends when: - Any player reaches Fort Level 5, OR - The Park deck runs out of friends

docs.title: Final Scoring
docs.text:
• Fort Level: Points for fort development
  • Friends in Yard: 1 point per unused friend
  • Pizza/Toys: Remaining resources worth points
  • Bonus Cards: Special scoring conditions
  • Best Friend Bonuses: Extra points for maintained friendships

docs.title: Turn Summary
docs.text:
1. Play Friend: Choose and play one friend card
  2. Others Follow: Other players may follow with matching suits
  3. Recruit: Spend Pizza/Toys to recruit new friends
  4. Build Fort: Advance fort level with resources
  5. Clean Up: Vulnerable friends can be stolen, draw to hand size

docs.title: Resource Costs (Typical)
docs.text: Action Cost Effect Recruit Basic Friend 1-2 Pizza Add to discard pile Recruit Best Friend 3-4 Pizza Add directly to hand Fort Level 1 1 Pizza + 1 Toy Basic abilities Fort Level 2 2 Pizza + 1 Toy Improved abilities Fort Level 3+ Higher costs Major powers

docs.title: Key Mechanics
docs.text:
• ✅ Following: Benefit from others' actions with matching cards
  • ✅ Friend Stealing: Recruit unused friends from opponents
  • ✅ Lookouts: Protect friends from being stolen
  • ✅ Fort Building: Permanent upgrades and scoring
  • ✅ Suit Matching: Required for following and some abilities

docs.title: Friend Management
docs.text:
• Balance using friends vs. keeping them safe from stealing
  • Lookout tokens are limited - use them strategically
  • Sometimes letting friends go leads to better recruits

docs.title: Following Strategy
docs.text:
• Follow aggressively early game for extra resources
  • Save matching cards for powerful friends
  • Consider what you're giving opponents when you play

docs.title: Fort Development
docs.text:
• Don't neglect fort building for friend recruitment
  • Higher fort levels provide significant advantages
  • Some abilities become crucial in late game

docs.title: Resource Balance
docs.text:
• Pizza is generally more versatile than Toys
  • Plan ahead for expensive fort upgrades
  • Some friends provide resources over time

docs.text:

  • Board Game Arena - Play online
  • How to Play Video - Learn the game
  • Designer Interview - Insights from Grant Rodiek

docs.title: HackClad (ハッククラッド)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Players: 2-4 | Time: 45 minutes | Complexity: 2.3/5 BGG Rating: 7.5/10 | Available on BGA: No

docs.title: Game Overview
docs.text:
HackClad is a witch-themed deck-building game where players take on the roles of witches competing to become the most accomplished spellcaster. You'll craft magical items, brew potions, cast spells, and gather mystical ingredients to build the most powerful deck of magical abilities.

The game combines traditional deck-building mechanics with unique witch-craft elements, creating a rich thematic experience where every card represents a step in your magical journey.

docs.title: Starting Decks (4 sets)
docs.text: Each player begins with an identical 10-card starting deck: - 7 Candle cards: Basic magic source (1 Magic each) - 3 Ritual cards: Basic spells for deck improvement

docs.title: Market Cards (120+ cards)
docs.text: Available for purchase during the game:

docs.title: Spell Cards
docs.text:
• Offensive Spells: Deal damage to opponents
  • Defensive Spells: Protect against attacks
  • Utility Spells: Provide various magical effects
  • Ritual Spells: Ongoing magical benefits

docs.title: Ingredient Cards
docs.text:
• Herbs: Common magical components
  • Crystals: Rare and powerful materials
  • Essences: Mystical substances for advanced magic
  • Artifacts: Powerful magical items

docs.title: Familiar Cards
docs.text:
• Animal Companions: Provide ongoing abilities
  • Magical Creatures: Powerful allies with unique effects
  • Spirits: Ethereal helpers with mystical powers

docs.title: Magic Tokens
docs.text: Wooden tokens representing magical energy used to purchase cards.

docs.title: Curse Cards
docs.text: Negative cards that clutter opponents' decks when attacked.

docs.title: Player Boards
docs.text: Individual boards for tracking health, magic production, and special abilities.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Give each player a starting deck of 10 cards (7 Candles, 3 Rituals)
  2. Shuffle starting decks individually and place face down as personal draw piles
  3. Draw opening hands of 5 cards each
  4. Create market by shuffling all market cards and revealing 6 face up
  5. Place magic tokens in a general supply
  6. Set up curse cards in a separate pile
  7. Each player starts with 10 Health points on their player board

Setup Tip

Organize market cards by type (Spells, Ingredients, Familiars) to make browsing easier during play.

docs.title: Game Round Structure
docs.text: Players take turns until someone reaches 0 Health or a victory condition is met.

docs.title: Your Turn Phase
docs.text:
1. Play Action Phase
  2. Play any number of cards from your hand
  3. Generate Magic from Candle cards and other sources
  4. Cast spells for their effects

  5. Use ingredient and familiar abilities

  6. Buy Phase

  7. Spend accumulated Magic to buy cards from the market
  8. Purchased cards go to your discard pile

  9. You may buy multiple cards if you have enough Magic

  10. Cleanup Phase

  11. Discard all played cards and remaining hand cards
  12. Draw a new hand of 5 cards
  13. If your deck is empty, shuffle your discard pile to form a new deck
  14. Refill market to 6 cards if needed

docs.title: Magic Generation
docs.text:
• Candle Cards: Provide 1 Magic each when played
  • Advanced Magic Sources: Provide more Magic or conditional bonuses
  • Rituals: Often provide Magic plus additional effects

docs.title: Spell Casting
docs.text:
• Instant Spells: Take effect immediately when played
  • Ongoing Spells: Remain in play for continued effects
  • Attack Spells: Force opponents to gain Curse cards or lose Health
  • Combination Spells: Gain bonuses when played with specific other cards

docs.title: Ingredients and Crafting
docs.text:
• Ingredient Cards: Provide Magic and may have special brewing effects
  • Crafting Combinations: Some ingredients work better when played together
  • Potion Effects: Create powerful one-time or ongoing magical effects

docs.title: Familiars
docs.text:
• Companion Effects: Provide ongoing benefits while in play
  • Summoning Costs: May require specific Magic types to play
  • Familiar Synergies: Some familiars boost the effects of spells or other familiars

docs.title: Attacking Opponents
docs.text:
• Play Attack spells to target other players
  • Attacked players must gain Curse cards or lose Health
  • Some spells affect all opponents simultaneously
  • Defensive spells can prevent or reduce attack effects

docs.title: Curse Cards
docs.text:
• Gained when attacked: Go directly into your discard pile
  • Clog your deck: Provide no beneficial effects when drawn
  • Removal methods: Some spells can remove Curses from your deck
  • Victory impact: Too many Curses slow your magical development

docs.title: Winning
docs.text: The game can end in several ways:

docs.title: Victory Conditions
docs.text:
1. Last Witch Standing: Be the only player with Health remaining
  2. Magical Mastery: First player to acquire 3 Master-level spell cards
  3. Deck Perfection: Build a deck worth 50+ Magic value points
  4. Familiar Bond: Control 5+ different Familiar types simultaneously

docs.title: End Game Scoring (if using point victory)
docs.text:
• Count total Magic value of all cards in deck, hand, and discard pile
  • Subtract 2 points per Curse card
  • Add bonus points for complete Familiar sets or spell combinations
  • Highest total wins

docs.title: Turn Summary
docs.text:
1. Action Phase: Play cards, generate Magic, cast spells
  2. Buy Phase: Purchase new cards with accumulated Magic
  3. Cleanup: Discard all, draw 5 new cards, refill market

docs.title: Starting Resources
docs.text:
• Starting Health: 10 points
  • Starting Hand: 5 cards
  • Starting Deck: 7 Candles (1 Magic each) + 3 Rituals

docs.title: Card Costs (Typical)
docs.text: Type Cost Range Examples Basic Spells 2-4 Magic Simple attack/defense Advanced Spells 5-8 Magic Powerful effects Master Spells 9+ Magic Game-changing abilities Basic Ingredients 1-3 Magic Common herbs, simple crystals Rare Ingredients 4-7 Magic Precious gems, essences Familiars 3-6 Magic Animal companions, spirits

docs.title: Key Mechanics
docs.text:
• ✅ Deck Building: Buy cards to improve your deck over time
  • ✅ Magic Generation: Play cards to generate Magic for purchases
  • ✅ Spell Combinations: Some cards work better together
  • ✅ Attack/Defense: Direct player interaction through combat spells
  • ✅ Curse Management: Avoid accumulating too many negative cards

docs.title: Early Game
docs.text:
• Focus on increasing Magic generation
  • Buy versatile cards that provide both Magic and utility
  • Don't neglect some defensive capabilities

docs.title: Mid Game
docs.text:
• Specialize in specific magical schools or familiar types
  • Start acquiring more powerful spells
  • Consider your victory condition path

docs.title: Late Game
docs.text:
• Pursue your chosen victory condition aggressively
  • Use attack spells to slow down opponents
  • Optimize your deck by removing weaker starting cards

docs.title: External Links
docs.text:
• BoardGameGeek - Reviews, ratings, and community discussion
  • Publisher Website - Official game information
  • Rules Video - Learn to play tutorial
  • Strategy Guide - Advanced gameplay tips

docs.title: イスタンブール選択と集中 (Istanbul: Choose & Write)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Players: 2-5 | Time: 60 minutes | Complexity: 2.8/5 BGG Rating: 7.3/10 | Available on BGA: Yes

docs.title: Game Overview
docs.text:
Istanbul: Choose & Write is a strategic roll-and-write game that captures the essence of the original Istanbul board game in a streamlined dice-based format. Players are merchants navigating the Grand Bazaar of Istanbul, using dice to collect goods, trade with customers, and earn precious rubies.

This game combines the tactical decision-making of the Istanbul series with the accessibility and simultaneous play of roll-and-write mechanics, creating an engaging experience where every die matters and timing is crucial.

docs.title: Player Sheets (5 copies each)
docs.text: Each player receives identical sheets containing: - Goods Track: Spaces for collecting Fabric, Spices, Fruit, Fish, and Jewelry - Caravan Track: Movement and bonus spaces - Mosque Bonus Track: Spiritual rewards path - Customer Cards: Available trading opportunities - Ruby Storage: Victory point tracking - Special Action Areas: Guild, Police, Smuggler locations

docs.title: Dice (15 dice total)
docs.text:
• 5 Red dice: Represent different merchant actions
  • 5 Blue dice: Alternative action options
  • 5 Yellow dice: Special bonus opportunities

docs.title: Action Cards (20 cards)
docs.text: Cards showing different combinations of symbols that correspond to dice faces.

docs.title: Ruby Tokens
docs.text: Physical tokens for tracking victory points.

docs.title: Starting Goods Markers
docs.text: Small markers to track initial resources.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Give each player a player sheet and a pencil/pen
  2. Each player marks their starting position on all tracks:
  3. Start with 2 goods of different types (player chooses)
  4. Place starting marker on space 0 of the Caravan track
  5. Begin with 0 rubies
  6. Shuffle action cards and place 4 face up in the center
  7. Set all 15 dice within reach of all players
  8. Place ruby tokens in a general supply

Setup Note

Players should use pencils as some decisions may need to be erased during the game.

docs.title: Game Round Structure
docs.text: Istanbul: Choose & Write is played over exactly 15 rounds. Each round follows this sequence:

docs.title: Phase 1: Roll Dice
docs.text:
• One player rolls all 15 dice (rotate this role each round)
  • All players simultaneously choose which dice to use for their turn

docs.title: Phase 2: Choose Actions
docs.text:
Each player selects exactly 4 dice from the 15 rolled dice to perform actions:

  1. Analyze available dice and their corresponding symbols
  2. Match dice symbols to action cards for bonuses
  3. Consider timing - once a die is claimed, others cannot use it
  4. Select 4 dice and announce your choices

docs.title: Phase 3: Resolve Actions
docs.text: Players simultaneously resolve their chosen dice:

docs.title: Good Collection Actions
docs.text:
• Fabric Die: Gain fabric goods and advance on fabric track
  • Spices Die: Collect spices and progress spice bonuses
  • Fruit Die: Gather fruit and unlock fruit chain rewards
  • Fish Die: Obtain fish and advance fishing opportunities
  • Jewelry Die: Acquire jewelry and progress luxury goods track

docs.title: Movement and Special Actions
docs.text:
• Caravan Die: Move your merchant around the bazaar for position bonuses
  • Mosque Die: Advance on the spiritual path for end-game bonuses
  • Guild Hall Die: Access guild member benefits
  • Police Station Die: Gain official permits and protection
  • Smuggler Den Die: Risky but potentially rewarding illegal trades

docs.title: Phase 4: Customer Trading
docs.text:
After resolving dice actions:

  1. Check customer requirements on your sheet
  2. Trade goods if you meet the requirements exactly
  3. Gain rubies as shown on completed customer cards
  4. Mark completed customers as finished

docs.title: Phase 5: Bonus Resolution
docs.text:
• Action Card Bonuses: If your dice match action card patterns, gain benefits
  • Track Bonuses: Some advancement on tracks provides immediate rewards
  • Combination Bonuses: Specific goods combinations may provide extra rubies

docs.title: Winning
docs.text: After 15 rounds, the game ends immediately. Players calculate final scores:

docs.title: Ruby Calculation
docs.text:
• Customer Rubies: Points earned from completed customer trades
  • Track Bonuses: End-game points from various track positions
  • Set Collection: Bonuses for having complete sets of goods
  • Mosque Bonuses: Spiritual advancement rewards
  • Action Card Sets: Bonuses for matching multiple action cards during the game

The player with the most rubies wins!

docs.title: Dice Symbol Guide
docs.text: Symbol Action Effect 🧵 Fabric Gain 1 Fabric, advance Fabric track 🌶️ Spices Gain 1 Spices, advance Spice track 🍎 Fruit Gain 1 Fruit, advance Fruit track 🐟 Fish Gain 1 Fish, advance Fish track 💎 Jewelry Gain 1 Jewelry, advance Jewelry track 🚶 Caravan Move 1-3 spaces on Caravan track 🕌 Mosque Advance 1 space on Mosque track 🏛️ Guild Access Guild Hall benefits 👮 Police Gain permits and protection 🗡️ Smuggler Risk/reward illegal trading

docs.title: Track Benefits Summary
docs.text:
• Goods Tracks: Provide immediate goods and end-game bonuses
  • Caravan Track: Unlocks special locations and movement bonuses
  • Mosque Track: Spiritual advancement with powerful end-game scoring

docs.title: Customer Card Types
docs.text:
• Simple Trades: Require 2-3 specific goods for 1-2 rubies
  • Complex Trades: Need 4-5 goods or specific combinations for 3-4 rubies
  • Luxury Trades: Demand rare combinations for 5+ rubies
  • Chain Customers: Link together for bonus rewards

docs.title: Early Game (Rounds 1-5)
docs.text:
• Focus on building basic goods collection
  • Establish position on multiple tracks
  • Don't ignore the Mosque track early

docs.title: Mid Game (Rounds 6-10)
docs.text:
• Start targeting specific customer requirements
  • Look for action card pattern opportunities
  • Balance goods collection with customer completion

docs.title: Late Game (Rounds 11-15)
docs.text:
• Prioritize high-value customers
  • Maximize end-game track positioning
  • Consider risk/reward of Smuggler actions

docs.title: General Tips
docs.text:
• Flexibility: Don't commit to one strategy too early
  • Timing: Sometimes waiting for better dice is worth it
  • Efficiency: Try to accomplish multiple goals with each die selection
  • Observation: Watch other players' sheets to anticipate die competition

docs.title: External Links
docs.text:
• BoardGameGeek - Reviews, ratings, and community discussion
  • Board Game Arena - Play online
  • How to Play Video - Tutorial and gameplay example
  • Strategy Guide - Advanced tactics discussion
  • Original Istanbul - The original board game this is based on

Istanbul: Choose & Write is a game by Rüdiger Dorn, published by AEG and Pegasus Spiele. This documentation is for educational purposes.

docs.title: National Economy Mesena (ナショナルエコノミー・メセナ)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Players: 1-4 | Time: 45 minutes | Complexity: 2.6/5 BGG Rating: 7.8/10 | Available on BGA: No

docs.title: Game Overview
docs.text:
National Economy Mesena is a cultural worker placement game where players are patrons of the arts, investing in cultural projects and supporting artists to build a thriving creative economy. This standalone expansion to National Economy introduces cultural production alongside traditional economic development.

Players manage workers, develop cultural institutions, and balance economic growth with artistic patronage. The game emphasizes long-term planning and the interconnection between cultural investment and economic prosperity.

docs.title: Worker Cards (80 cards)
docs.text: Each worker has: - Wages: Cost to employ the worker - Skills: Specific abilities and bonuses - Cultural Affinity: Preference for artistic or commercial work - Specializations: Unique effects when used in specific contexts

docs.title: Building Cards (60 cards)
docs.text:
• Cultural Buildings: Theaters, museums, art galleries, concert halls
  • Commercial Buildings: Shops, factories, offices, restaurants
  • Mixed Buildings: Libraries, cultural centers, educational institutions

docs.title: Art Project Cards (40 cards)
docs.text:
• Visual Arts: Paintings, sculptures, installations
  • Performing Arts: Plays, concerts, dance performances
  • Literary Arts: Books, poetry, journalism
  • Cultural Events: Festivals, exhibitions, cultural celebrations

docs.title: Currency (Coins and Cultural Points)
docs.text:
• Gold Coins: Standard economic currency
  • Cultural Points: Represent artistic and social value
  • Prestige Tokens: Recognition for cultural achievements

docs.title: Player Boards (4 boards)
docs.text: Track economic development, cultural influence, and special abilities.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Give each player a starting deck of 8 worker cards
  2. Create building market with 6 face-up building cards
  3. Set up art project display with 4 available projects
  4. Each player starts with 7 coins and 1 cultural point
  5. Place workers - each player draws 5 workers as starting hand
  6. Set up cultural calendar showing seasonal bonuses

Cultural Calendar

The cultural calendar provides different bonuses each round, representing seasonal cultural events and funding opportunities.

docs.title: Round Structure
docs.text: Each round represents a season in the cultural year.

docs.title: Phase 1: Cultural Planning
docs.text:
• Reveal new cultural calendar bonus for this round
  • Players may spend cultural points for early advantages
  • Adjust cultural market based on seasonal demands

docs.title: Phase 2: Worker Deployment
docs.text: Players take turns placing workers on available actions:

docs.title: Economic Actions
docs.text:
• Commercial Work: Gain coins based on worker's commercial skill
  • Resource Gathering: Collect materials needed for cultural projects
  • Building Construction: Build new cultural or commercial facilities
  • Market Trading: Buy/sell goods and cultural artifacts

docs.title: Cultural Actions
docs.text:
• Artistic Creation: Commission or create art projects
  • Cultural Support: Fund existing cultural institutions
  • Public Performance: Organize events for cultural points and coins
  • Education: Train workers in cultural skills

docs.title: Phase 3: Cultural Resolution
docs.text:
• Complete Art Projects: Finish commissioned works for bonuses
  • Cultural Institution Benefits: Gain ongoing effects from cultural buildings
  • Public Recognition: Convert achievements into prestige tokens
  • Seasonal Bonuses: Apply cultural calendar effects

docs.title: Phase 4: Economic Resolution
docs.text:
• Pay Worker Wages: All employed workers must be paid
  • Building Maintenance: Some buildings require upkeep
  • Investment Returns: Gain income from commercial buildings
  • Worker Development: Upgrade workers with new skills

docs.title: Art Projects
docs.text:
• Commission: Spend resources to begin art projects
  • Completion: Requires specific worker skills and time
  • Benefits: Provide cultural points, prestige, and ongoing effects
  • Synergies: Some projects work better when combined

docs.title: Cultural Buildings
docs.text:
• Construction: Requires both coins and cultural points
  • Operation: Need skilled workers to function effectively
  • Benefits: Provide ongoing cultural and economic advantages
  • Prestige: Major cultural buildings provide significant prestige

docs.title: Worker Development
docs.text:
• Skills Training: Improve worker abilities over time
  • Specialization: Focus workers on cultural or commercial tracks
  • Cultural Education: Train workers in artistic skills
  • Leadership: Some workers can manage cultural institutions

docs.title: Resource Management
docs.text:
• Balance: Maintain balance between coins and cultural points
  • Investment: Cultural investments pay off over time
  • Prestige Value: High prestige attracts better workers and projects

docs.title: Winning
docs.text: The game ends after a fixed number of rounds (varies by player count).

docs.title: Economic Value
docs.text:
• Coins: Remaining money
  • Buildings: Commercial and cultural building values
  • Workers: Total value of trained worker force

docs.title: Cultural Impact
docs.text:
• Art Projects: Points for completed cultural works
  • Cultural Buildings: Ongoing cultural influence
  • Prestige Tokens: Recognition and status
  • Cultural Legacy: Bonus points for diverse cultural investments

docs.title: Synergy Bonuses
docs.text:
• Cultural-Economic Balance: Bonuses for balanced development
  • Artistic Collections: Sets of related art projects
  • Cultural Districts: Connected cultural buildings
  • Master Artisan: Workers who achieved highest skill levels

docs.title: Action Summary
docs.text: Action Cost Effect Commercial Work Worker wages Gain coins Cultural Work Worker wages + materials Gain cultural points Build Commercial Coins Economic building Build Cultural Coins + cultural points Cultural building Art Commission Resources + cultural points Begin art project Cultural Event Cultural points Immediate benefits + prestige

docs.title: Worker Skills
docs.text:
• Commercial: Better at economic activities
  • Artistic: Better at cultural projects
  • Leadership: Can manage multiple workers
  • Specialized: Expert in specific cultural areas

docs.title: Building Benefits
docs.text:
• Theater: Bonus cultural points from performances
  • Museum: Ongoing prestige generation
  • Art Gallery: Bonus for visual art projects
  • Cultural Center: Versatile cultural bonuses
  • Library: Worker education benefits

docs.title: Balanced Development
docs.text:
• Don't neglect either economic or cultural development
  • Cultural investments often pay off more in the long term
  • Some of the highest scoring comes from synergy bonuses

docs.title: Worker Management
